channel.title: Notes on Knowledge x Base
channel.description: Recent content in Notes on Knowledge x Base

item.title: Realism and Anti-Realism
item.description: 1. Introduction Notes 1:2 Aim of this book: To make clear what is really at stake in the contemporary realism debate Claim: no other book has succeeded in doing that Being more accessible than other books by containing less philosophical jargon 2:1 Definition of realism: Realism about a particular domain is the conjunction (x and y) of the theses: (i) the existence thesis: there are facts or entities distinctive of that domain (ii) the independence thesis: their existence and nature is in some important sense objective and mind-independent 2:2 Existence thesis (elaboration): Caveat: involves quantification over entities and facts Entities: referents of singular terms Facts: aspects of the world represented by whole declarative sentences Those who distinguished existence and independence thesis only quantified it over individuals Q: why is the involvement of both facts and entities awkward?

item.title: L-values and R-values
item.description: Assignment operators an operand that legally can be on the left side of an assignment operator is an l-value. one that can be on the right side is an r-value not all l-values are r-values, but not all r-values are l-values.

item.title: Pointers
item.description: Definition define an integer and reserves a location in memory for this specific variable take an integer pointer: int *pointer this defines an integer pointer such that its content is the address of another place in memory int var var = 10 pointer = &var this defines an integer var, and &var is the address of a specific place in memory where the integer is stored it also points the variable pointer to var so that when checking out the value *pointer*, we get the content of var, which is 10 With arrays pointers can also be appointed to arrays so that using (pointer + 1) points to certain array element matr[1].

item.title: Casing and spacing
item.description: best practice: writing folder and file names lower-case, with no spaces, and words separated by hyphens (not underscores).

item.title: Python sets
item.description: a python set is unordered and unindexed, they cannot be accessed through an index they also do not allow duplicated values myset = {"ten","one","three","four", "three"} print(mysetpython # Output: {'four', 'one', 'three', 'ten'}

item.title: Python tuples
item.description: a python tuple is an immutable, ordered collection once it is created it cannot be updated mytuple = ("string",pi)

item.title: Round-off errors
item.description: Page 27, paragraph 2, line 8-17 Since e^-20^ is a very small number and each term in the series can be rather large (of the order of 10^8^,it is clear that other terms as large as 10^8^, but negative, must cancel the figures in front of the decimal point and some behind as well. Since a computer can only hold a fixed number of significant figures, all those in front of the decimal point are not only useless, they are crowding out needed figures at the right end of the number.

item.title: The loss-of-precision theorem
item.description: Subtraction If b and c are positive normalized floating-point binary machine numbers with $b < c$ and $$ 2^{-r} \leq 1 - \frac{c}{b} \leq 2^{-s}, $$ Then at most $r$ and at least $s$ significant binary bits are lost in the subtraction $b-c$.

item.title: Dimensional analysis
item.description: Notations To denote that something is a unit of $Y$, we use $ \left[ Y \right]$ = unit of Y I always get this the other way around. Facepalm.

item.title: Non-conservative forces
item.description: Question What on earth is a non-conservative force if all underlying forces of friction and other contact forces operate as conservative force on a microsopic level? This one partially answers my question here Hint: Mechanical energy is the keyword. Another answer from stackexchange: Q: “How do many conservative forces come together to make a non-conservative one?” So my question how do several different Electromagnetic forces come together to make a new frictional force which is non-conservative in nature

item.title: Unit vectors
item.description: dot product perpendicular/orthogonal components are 0 $\hat{i} \cdot \hat{j} = \hat{j} \cdot \hat{k} = \hat{k} \cdot \hat{i}$ and so on and so forth vector product I generally find the right hand rule to be very straight forward index $\times$ middle = thumb

item.title: Polar coordinates
item.description: Conventions $ x = r\cos{\theta} $ $ y = r\sin{\theta} $ $ r = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2} $ $ \phi = \arctan{\frac{y}{x}} $

item.title: Absolute space
item.description: The Cartesian body motion of a body is a change of relation to the bodies that surround it. concept of inertia a body’s motion will be preserved unless caused to deviate from its path so not a function of its spatial relations to other bodies but of its causal relation The Newtonian body a body’s motion is not a function of its spatial relations to other objects but rather of whether forces are impressed on it.

item.title: Solid angles
item.description: unit: steradian (sr) analogous to plane angle, which is defined by arc length and radius, but unlike the plane angle, it is defined by the surface area of a sphere subtended by the lines and by the radius of that sphere (squared, for a correct dimensional analysis. $\theta = \frac{l}{dr}$ $\Omega = \frac{a}{r^2}$ unlike the plane angle, it cannot be conceived of without reference to an arbitrary sphere. this was a pretty intuitive and sympathetic explanation

item.title: Mechanics (Core 1)
item.description: Vectors Notations the basis is the set of unit vectors from which all others are built perpendicular axes normally have basis vectors $\boldsymbol{\hat{i},\hat{j},\hat{k}}$ helpful to remember: i = 8 o’clock, j = 4 o’clock, k = 12 o’clock (standard) this is right-handed axes (anti-clockwise) $\boldsymbol{\hat{a}} = \frac{\boldsymbol{a}}{\left|a\right|}$ Components $\theta$ taken from x-axis $a_x = a\cos{\theta}$ $a_y = a\sin{\theta}$ $\tan{\theta} = \frac{a_y}{a_x}$ $\left|a\right| = \sqrt{a_x^2+a_y^2}$ 3D components pretty much compliant with 2D and 1D examples, but the concept of an angle might be harder to visualise, we rely on the unit vectors as it’s a much easier system.
